channel.title: RICH RYAN on RICH RYAN
channel.description: Recent content in RICH RYAN on RICH RYAN

item.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Theory, Fall 2014
item.description:
Section notes for Intermediate Microeconomic Theory, ECON 401, with Professor Tilman Börgers

  1. Happy Labor Market Friday, valuing time, the rationality hypothesis, the transitive property, choices and consistent rankings
  2. CES utility functions, convex preferences, depicting indifference curves
  3. Checking rationality continued, demand functions, Cobb–Douglas preferences, monotonic transformations, more CES preferences
  4. Income and substitution effects, in pictures, numerically calculating the income and substitution effects, the sign of the substitution effect
  5. Marshalian demand, elasticities, Hicksian (compensated) demand, verifying that the Slutsky equation holds
  6. Comparative statics: prices, complements and substitutes, perfect complements, perfect complements, slightly imperfect substitutes, slightly imperfect complements
  7. Hicksian demand with perfect substitutes, labor supply, labor supply with perfect substitutes, labor-supply elasticity
  8. Firms’ profit maximization, isoquants, cost minimization, cost minimization with Cobb–Douglas technology, conditional factor demand functions
  9. Cost functions and returns to scale, \(p \geq \min \text{AC}(q) \), returns to scale and Cobb–Douglas
  10. Exam review, quadratic marginal cost, circle isoquants
  11. Equilibrium supply and demand, taxes, it doesn’t matter who pays the tax, taxation with linear demand and supply, nonlinear demand and elasticities: \[ \frac{d p}{d \tau} = \frac{\eta}{\eta + \varepsilon}\]
  12. Equilibrium in several interacting markets, partial equilibrium
  13. Equilibrium in several markets continued, short- vs long-run cost
  14. The change in consumer surplus, the slope of the demand curve, compensating variation, equivalent variation, for normal goods: \[ \text{EV} < \text{CS loss} < \text{CV}, \] for quasilinear utility: EV = CV
  15. Markets and efficiency; EV = old prices, new utility; CV = new prices, old utility; with transfers, all agents prefer equilibrium to all other allocations; equivalent and compensating variation with perfect complements and linear utility
  16. Tax incidence analysis: deadweight loss, Professor Börgers’s milk farm, Arrow’s Impossibility theorem, the Condorcet cycle
  17. Monopoly, the markup: \[\frac{P(Q)}{\text{MC}(Q)} = \frac{1}{1- 1/ |\varepsilon|}, \] first-degree price discrimination
  18. Price discrimination: first-, second-, and third-degree price discrimination, sale in different markets, \[p_1 > p_2 \iff |\varepsilon_1| < |\varepsilon_2|, \] Professor Börgers’s cat farm
  19. A very brief introduction to game theory, Nash equilibrium, chicken, modified picnic, modified traffic, beauty contest
  20. Game theory continued: Bertrand and Cournot, Braess’s paradox, Bertrand with differentiated products
  21. Risk and uncertainty, lotteries, St. Petersburg paradox, concavity and risk aversion, von Neumann Morgenstern utility function
  22. Externalities, a negative externality in consumption, strategic interaction and externalities
  23. The picnic example continued, moral hazard, thanks

item.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Theory, Fall 2018
item.description:
Materials for Intermediate Microeconomic Theory, ECON 401, with Dr. Chris Proulx.

The course website is here. These notes improve upon the notes from the Winter 2015 semester.

Materials for a significantly different version of the class with Professor Tilman Börgers are available here.

item.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Theory, Winter 2015
item.description:
Section notes for Intermediate Microeconomic Theory, ECON 401, with Dr. Chris Proulx. An improved version of these notes is available here.

Notes

  1. Introduction, review of mathematics
  2. Budget sets, preferences
  3. Where we are: constraints, preferences, utility functions
  4. Utility functions
  5. Choice
  6. Problems
  7. Comparative statics and the WARP police
  8. WARP/SARP, Slutsky
  9. The Slutsky equation
  10. Endowments
  11. Intertemporal choice
  12. Consumer’s surplus, EV, CV
  13. Market demand
  14. A notion of equilibrium
  15. Technology and profit maximization
  16. Cost minimization
  17. Cost curves
  18. Firm supply
  19. Industry supply and brief review for the exam
  20. Monopoly
  21. Getting to know the customer: Monopoly behavior
  22. A too brief introduction to game theory
  23. Applications of game theory: Oligopoly
  24. The Edgeworth box: Exchange and general equilibrium
  25. Exchange continued
  26. More Edgeworth box and auctions
  27. Externalities
  28. Asymmetric information

Yet more Edgeworth box

  • Leontief
  • Quasilinear

item.title: Initial Claims
item.description:
Here are initial-claims data, which were covered in a recent NY Times article. I try and replicate a few of the figures detailed in the article.

Data on initial claims are available at FRED by browsing data by Category > Population, Employment, & Labor Markets > Weekly Initial Claims and selecting Initial Claims.

Here is the R code for retrieving and plotting these data. Data on initial claims from March are highlighted in orange.

# Load packages
library(tidyverse)
library(tidyquant)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggthemes)

my_blue <- "purple1"
my_orange <- "orangered1"
my_shade <- "gray66"

claims <- tq_get("ICSA", get = "economic.data", from = "1800-01-01")
head(claims)

## # A tibble: 6 x 3
##   symbol date        price
##   <chr>  <date>      <int>
## 1 ICSA   1967-01-07 208000
## 2 ICSA   1967-01-14 207000
## 3 ICSA   1967-01-21 217000
## 4 ICSA   1967-01-28 204000
## 5 ICSA   1967-02-04 216000
## 6 ICSA   1967-02-11 229000

tail(claims)

## # A tibble: 6 x 3
##   symbol date         price
##   <chr>  <date>       <int>
## 1 ICSA   2020-02-22  220000
## 2 ICSA   2020-02-29  217000
## 3 ICSA   2020-03-07  211000
## 4 ICSA   2020-03-14  282000
## 5 ICSA   2020-03-21 3307000
## 6 ICSA   2020-03-28 6648000

# Convert claims to millions
dat <- claims %>% 
  mutate(price = price / 1e+06)

dat_early <- dat %>% 
  filter(
    date >= ymd("2004-01-01") &
    date <  ymd("2020-03-01"))

dat_late <- dat %>% 
  filter(date >= ymd("2020-03-01"))

last_date <- max(dat_late$date)
last_lvl <- dat_late$price[[which(dat_late$date == max(dat_late$date))]]

my_breaks <- seq(0,7)
my_labels <- paste(my_breaks)
my_labels[[length(my_labels)]] <- "7 million"

plt <- ggplot() +
  geom_col(mapping =  aes(x = date, y = price),
           data = dat_early,
           color = my_blue, position = "identity") +
  # Highlight March 2020
  geom_col(data = dat_late,
             mapping = aes(x = date, y = price),
             color = my_orange) +
  xlab("") + ggtitle("Initial jobless claims") +
  # Label y-axis for wsj theme
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = my_breaks,
                     labels = my_labels, 
                     limits = c(0,7.5)) +
  # Label last observation, set off 1 year
  annotate("text", 
           x = last_date - 360,
           y = last_lvl, 
           label = paste0(last_lvl, "\n", 
                         month(last_date, label = TRUE), ", ", day(last_date)),
           color = my_orange,
           hjust = 0.85) +
  # Use sans serif font instead of mono, use gray color
  theme_wsj(base_family = "sans", 
            color = "gray", 
            title_family = "sans")
# Display the plot
(plt)

FRED also provides recession dates. These dates can be used to add recession shading to the developing figure.

The goal is highlighting recessions. From the NBER’s website:

Contractions (recessions) start at the peak of a business cycle and end at the trough.

Note: The FRED series USRECM indicates periods “from the peak through the trough”; whereas, USREC indicates periods “from the period following the peak through the trough.” (Both series are monthly.)

recess <- tq_get("USRECM", get = "economic.data", from = "1800-01-01")
tail(recess)

## # A tibble: 6 x 3
##   symbol date       price
##   <chr>  <date>     <int>
## 1 USRECM 2019-10-01     0
## 2 USRECM 2019-11-01     0
## 3 USRECM 2019-12-01     0
## 4 USRECM 2020-01-01     0
## 5 USRECM 2020-02-01     0
## 6 USRECM 2020-03-01     0

To use geom_rect(), the beginning and end of recessions are needed.

# Create groups based recessions
recess_dat <- recess %>% 
  arrange(date) %>% 
  mutate(same = 1 - (price == lag(price))) %>% 
  # Remove first row, an NA, for cumulative sum
  filter(date > min(recess$date)) %>% 
  mutate(era = cumsum(same)) %>% 
  # Filter only recessions
  filter(price == 1)

Now the recessions are grouped according to era. The following code groups the data by recessions and keeps the first and last element of the group.

recess_dat <- recess_dat %>% 
  group_by(era) %>% 
  # Unncessary, but to be sure...
  arrange(date) %>% 
  filter(row_number() == 1 | row_number() == n())

# Now reshape the data wide.
# Each row will contain the start and end dates of a recession.
recess_dat <- recess_dat %>% 
  mutate(junk = row_number()) %>% 
  mutate(begin_end = case_when(
    junk == 1 ~ "begin",
    junk == 2 ~ "end"
  ))

recess_wide <- recess_dat %>%
  ungroup() %>% 
  select(symbol, price, date, era, begin_end) %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = begin_end, values_from = date)

We can check these dates against the official dates published at the NBER’s website.

tail(recess_wide)

## # A tibble: 6 x 5
##   symbol price   era begin      end       
##   <chr>  <int> <dbl> <date>     <date>    
## 1 USRECM     1    56 1973-11-01 1975-03-01
## 2 USRECM     1    58 1980-01-01 1980-07-01
## 3 USRECM     1    60 1981-07-01 1982-11-01
## 4 USRECM     1    62 1990-07-01 1991-03-01
## 5 USRECM     1    64 2001-03-01 2001-11-01
## 6 USRECM     1    66 2007-12-01 2009-06-01

These dates agree with the NBER dates.

Adding recession shading is straightforward:

plt2 <- plt +
  geom_rect(mapping = aes(xmin = begin, xmax = end,
                          ymin = 0, ymax = 7),
            data = filter(recess_wide,
                          begin >= min(dat_early$date)), 
            fill = my_shade,
            alpha = 0.6) 
(plt2)

To get a sense of the initial claims, here are all the data:

ggplot() +
  geom_rect(mapping = aes(xmin = begin, xmax = end,
                          ymin = 0, ymax = 7),
            data = filter(recess_wide,
                          begin >= min(dat$date)), 
            fill = my_shade,
            alpha = 0.6) + 
  geom_col(mapping =  aes(x = date, y = price),
           data = dat,
           color = my_blue, position = "identity") +
  xlab("") + ggtitle("Initial jobless claims") +
  # Label y-axis for wsj theme
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = my_breaks,
                     labels = my_labels, 
                     limits = c(0,7.5)) +
  theme_wsj(base_family = "sans", 
            color = "gray", 
            title_family = "sans")

item.title: Happy Labor Market Friday!
item.description:
Here are data from the latest Employment Situation. These graphs attempt to replicate those published by the NY Times.

Unemployment rate or number of unemployed as a percentage of the labor force:

# Load packages
library(tidyquant)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggthemes)

mygray <- "gray66"

ur <- tq_get("UNRATE", get = "economic.data", from = "2010-01-01")
ur <- ur %>% 
  mutate(series = "Unemployment rate")
last_date <- max(ur$date)
last_lvl <- ur$price[[which(ur$date == max(ur$date))]]
ggplot(data = ur) +
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = price), size = 1.1, color = mygray) + 
  # Highlight last observation
  geom_point(data = filter(ur, date == last_date), 
             mapping = aes(x = date, y = price),
             size = 5) +
  xlab("") + ylab("Percent") + ggtitle("Unemployment rate") +
  # Label y-axis for wsj theme
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(4, 6, 8, 10),
                     labels = c("4", "6", "8", "10%")) +
  # Label last observation 
  annotate("text", x = last_date, y = last_lvl, label = paste0(last_lvl), 
           color = "black", vjust = -1.5) +
  # Use sans serif font instead of mono, use gray color
  theme_wsj(base_family = "sans", color = "gray", title_family = "sans", base_size = 12)

The unemployment rate was last_lvl.

payems <- tq_get("PAYEMS", get = "economic.data", from = "2016-11-01") 
payems <- payems %>% 
  mutate(change_jobs = price - lag(price),
         mycat = date == max(date)) %>% 
  filter(!is.na(change_jobs))
  
last_date <- max(payems$date)
last_lvl <- payems$change_jobs[[which(payems$date == max(payems$date))]]

segment_height <- 100
ggplot(data = payems) +
  geom_col(mapping = aes(x = date, y = change_jobs, color = mycat, fill = mycat),
           inherit.aes = FALSE) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(100, 200, 300, 400),
                     labels = c("100", "200", "300", "400 thousand"),
                     limits = c(0, 400)) +
  # Label last observation 
  annotate("text", x = last_date, y = last_lvl + segment_height, 
           label = paste0("+", last_lvl, "\nNov 2019"), 
           color = "black") +  
  annotate("segment", x = last_date, xend = last_date, 
           y = last_lvl, yend = last_lvl + segment_height - 25,
           linetype = "dashed") +
  # Color the bars
  scale_fill_manual(values = c(mygray, "black")) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c(mygray, "black")) +
  # Turn off legend
  guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE) +
  ggtitle("Monthly change in jobs") +
  theme_wsj(base_family = "sans", color = "gray", title_family = "sans", base_size = 12) +
  # Put grid lines on top
  theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = NA),
        panel.ontop = TRUE)

item.title: The Economics of Sustainability, Fall 2019
item.description:
Materials for The Economics of Sustainability, BEPP 401, with Professor Thomas P. Lyon.

The course website is here.

item.title: Many models in R
item.description:
Introduction

This is an example of using R to run many regressions and collect a single regression coefficient from each model. The code uses R’s list-columns feature.

Data

library(forcats)
library(tidyquant)

date_start <- "1960-01-01"
dat <- tq_get(c("UNRATE", "CPIAUCSL", "CPILFESL"), get = "economic.data",
             from = date_start)
ur <- dat %>% 
  filter(symbol == "UNRATE") %>% 
  rename(ur = price) %>% 
  select(-symbol)
dat <- filter(dat, symbol != "UNRATE")

Check that the unemployment-rate data are read in correctly:

head(ur)

## # A tibble: 6 x 2
##   date          ur
##   <date>     <dbl>
## 1 1960-01-01   5.2
## 2 1960-02-01   4.8
## 3 1960-03-01   5.4
## 4 1960-04-01   5.2
## 5 1960-05-01   5.1
## 6 1960-06-01   5.4

tail(ur)

## # A tibble: 6 x 2
##   date          ur
##   <date>     <dbl>
## 1 2018-12-01   3.9
## 2 2019-01-01   4  
## 3 2019-02-01   3.8
## 4 2019-03-01   3.8
## 5 2019-04-01   3.6
## 6 2019-05-01   3.6

Generate inflation data as percent change from one year ago:

$$ \text{percent change from year ago} = \left( \frac{ x_t }{ x_{t-12} } - 1 \right) \times 100. $$

dat <- dat %>% 
  group_by(symbol) %>% 
  mutate(infl = (price/lag(price, n = 12) - 1)*100) %>% 
  drop_na()

# Rename series
dat <- dat %>% 
  mutate(series_name = case_when(symbol == "CPILFESL" ~ "Less food and energy",
                                 symbol == "CPIAUCSL" ~ "All items"))

Plot the data:

ggplot(data = dat) +
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = infl, color = series_name)) +
  labs(x = "", y = "Percent", color = "") + 
  ggtitle("Inflation") +
  theme_bw()

Regressions

The goal now is seeing the relationship between the unemployment rate and inflation. Specifically, we’re interested in the regressions $$ \text{inflation}_t = \alpha + \beta \; \text{unemployment rate}_t + \varepsilon_t $$ for each of the inflation series. We’re interested in reporting the $ \beta $s.

To do so, we need to get the data in this form:

dat <- dat %>% 
  left_join(ur, by = "date")
head(dat)

## # A tibble: 6 x 6
## # Groups:   symbol [1]
##   symbol   date       price  infl series_name    ur
##   <chr>    <date>     <dbl> <dbl> <chr>       <dbl>
## 1 CPIAUCSL 1961-01-01  29.8 1.60  All items     6.6
## 2 CPIAUCSL 1961-02-01  29.8 1.46  All items     6.9
## 3 CPIAUCSL 1961-03-01  29.8 1.46  All items     6.9
## 4 CPIAUCSL 1961-04-01  29.8 0.914 All items     7  
## 5 CPIAUCSL 1961-05-01  29.8 0.913 All items     7.1
## 6 CPIAUCSL 1961-06-01  29.8 0.777 All items     6.9

tail(dat)

## # A tibble: 6 x 6
## # Groups:   symbol [1]
##   symbol   date       price  infl series_name             ur
##   <chr>    <date>     <dbl> <dbl> <chr>                <dbl>
## 1 CPILFESL 2018-12-01  260.  2.21 Less food and energy   3.9
## 2 CPILFESL 2019-01-01  261.  2.15 Less food and energy   4  
## 3 CPILFESL 2019-02-01  261.  2.08 Less food and energy   3.8
## 4 CPILFESL 2019-03-01  261.  2.04 Less food and energy   3.8
## 5 CPILFESL 2019-04-01  262.  2.07 Less food and energy   3.6
## 6 CPILFESL 2019-05-01  262.  2.00 Less food and energy   3.6

Now we’re interested in a function that regresses infl on ur and returns the coefficient on ur. The input of the function will be data frame. We’re interested in data frames because there are essentially two datasets, one for each of the inflation series. This is done using R’s nest, which creates a new data structure:

dat <- dat %>% 
  group_by(series_name) %>% 
  nest()
dat

## # A tibble: 2 x 2
##   series_name          data              
##   <chr>                <list>            
## 1 All items            <tibble [701 x 5]>
## 2 Less food and energy <tibble [701 x 5]>

Each row of the data column is data frame:

dat$data[[1]]

## # A tibble: 701 x 5
##    symbol   date       price  infl    ur
##    <chr>    <date>     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
##  1 CPIAUCSL 1961-01-01  29.8 1.60    6.6
##  2 CPIAUCSL 1961-02-01  29.8 1.46    6.9
##  3 CPIAUCSL 1961-03-01  29.8 1.46    6.9
##  4 CPIAUCSL 1961-04-01  29.8 0.914   7  
##  5 CPIAUCSL 1961-05-01  29.8 0.913   7.1
##  6 CPIAUCSL 1961-06-01  29.8 0.777   6.9
##  7 CPIAUCSL 1961-07-01  29.9 1.25    7  
##  8 CPIAUCSL 1961-08-01  29.9 1.11    6.6
##  9 CPIAUCSL 1961-09-01  30.0 1.25    6.7
## 10 CPIAUCSL 1961-10-01  30.0 0.773   6.5
## # ... with 691 more rows

Now we’re interested in a function that takes one of these data frames as inputs.

my_reg <- function(df) {
  fit <- lm(infl ~ ur, data = df)
  # Return the unemployment-rate coefficient
  return(fit$coefficients[["ur"]])
}

And we want to use R’s map function to return the coefficients:

dat <- dat %>% 
  mutate(coefficient = map(data, my_reg)) %>% 
  unnest(coefficient)
dat

## # A tibble: 2 x 3
##   series_name          data               coefficient
##   <chr>                <list>                   <dbl>
## 1 All items            <tibble [701 x 5]>       0.230
## 2 Less food and energy <tibble [701 x 5]>       0.371

The dataset now contains the coefficients from the two regressions.

item.title: Converting the Jekyll website to Hugo and Blogdown
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Introduction
  • Footnotes
  • $ \LaTeX{} $
  • Emojis
  • Alerts and helpful hints
  • Table of contents

Introduction

Using Jekyll as a static site generator with GitHug Pages on a Windows computer required setting up an Ubuntu environment to issue a jekyll serve command. Doing so became annoying. Another big selling point was the inclusion of R code in posts, a feature that I quickly became accostomed to after writing a couple of course websites in R Markdown and publishing them with GitHub Pages.1

The following sections cover some neat features.

Footnotes

Footnotes are easy to include—just like this.2

Footnotes are easy to include---just like this.[^fn:fn-example]

$ \LaTeX{} $

Including inline $ \LaTeX{} $ math is done by wrapping expressions in a single $. Multiline expressions are wrapped in $$. For example,

$$ \begin{equation} \label{eq:some-eq} \mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \beta + \varepsilon, \end{equation} $$

which can be referred to as $ \eqref{eq:some-eq} $. Automatic equation numbering is accomplished by including the HTML code

<script type="text/x-mathjax-config">
MathJax.Hub.Config({
  TeX: { equationNumbers: { autoNumber: "AMS" } }
});
</script>

in a post. See http://docs.mathjax.org/en/latest/tex.html#automatic-equation-numbering.

I’ve found including all of the math content on a single line the best way to

Emojis

An emoji like 🌊 can be included using:

An emoji like : ocean : can be included

Alerts and helpful hints

Alerts and hints can be included as

Here’s a tip or note…

Here’s some important information…

Table of contents

A table of contents can be added to R Mardown posts by adding the following options to YAML:

output: 
  blogdown::html_page:
    toc: true

and using {{% toc %}} anywhere in the document.

  1. See, for example, some notes for Intermediate Macroeconomic Theory or Intermediate Microeconomic Theory. ^
  2. A footnote. ^

item.title: Macroeconomic Theory I, Fall 2016
item.description:
Materials for Macroeconomic Theory I, ECON 605, with Professors Dmitriy Stolyarov and John Leahy.

The improved Fall 2017 notes represent meaningful learning on my part—many of the details are smoothed out in the updated notes. I preserve the Fall 2016 notes as a reference to those who used them. The preservation also represents a desire not to obliterate the hard work that went into them.

Stolyarov

  • ECON 605 Stolyarov notes
  • ECON 605 Stolyarov review

Leahy

  • ECON 605 Leahy notes

item.title: Macroeconomic Theory I, Fall 2017
item.description:
Materials for Macroeconomic Theory I, ECON 605, with Professors Dmitriy Stolyarov and John Leahy.

The improved Fall 2017 notes represent meaningful learning on my part—many of the details are smoothed out in the updated notes. I preserve the Fall 2016 notes as a reference to those who used them. The preservation also represents a desire not to obliterate the hard work that went into them.

Stolyarov

  • ECON 605 Stolyarov notes
  • Notes on an alternative asset-market structure
  • The effect of corporate taxation on wages in the neoclassical growth model without labor choice
  • Slide deck for review session
  • Handout on whether capital jumps

Leahy

  • An example of discrete dynamic programming using McCall’s search model
  • Slide deck for review session
  • Worked examples of dynamic programming
  • ECON 605 Leahy notes

item.title: Financial Economics, Winter 2016
item.description:
Materials for Financial Economics, ECON 435, with Professor Pablo Ottonello

Notes

  1. What an interest rate is, the value of money over time, annuities, perpetuities, bonds
  2. Present value, future value, internal rate of return, effective annual rate, annual percentage rate, coupon rate, zero-coupon bond, yield to maturity
  3. Bonds continued, stocks
  4. Valuing stocks
  5. Happy Labor Market Friday, Exam 1 solutions
  6. Random variables, variance, standard deviation, diversification in stock portfolios
  7. The volatility of a large portfolio, risk-free saving and borrowing
  8. The efficient portfolio, CAPM
  9. Identifying a stock’s \(\alpha\), Fama–French–Carhart
  10. Capital structure, unlevered equity, levered equity, Modigliani–Miler
  11. MM continued, Vandelay Industries, interest tax shield
  12. Happy Labor Market Friday, \(V^{\text{L}} = V^{\text{U}} + \text{PV}(\text{interest tax shield})\), financial options, call option, put option, option writer, strike or exercise price, American option, European option, long and short positions, option premium, open interest, at-the-money, in-the-money, out-of-the-money, deep in-the-money or out-of-the-money
  13. Put–call parity, \(S + P = \text{PV}(K) + C\), \(\text{PV}(K) = K - D(K)\)
  14. A call option graphically, more put-call parity, thanks

Problem sets and proposed solutions

  1. Problem set 1
  2. Problem set 2
  3. Problem set 3
  4. Problem set 4
  5. Problem set 5
  6. Problem set 6
  7. Problem set 7
  8. Problem set 8
  9. Problem set 9
  10. Problem set 10
  11. Proposed solutions to the Second Midterm Exam
